bibl.title: Letter from Thomas J. Michie to Philip Showalter Hench, March 4, 1942

div1.p: Michie thanks Hench for the information on his relative, R.E. Lee Michie, whose daughter is sending Michie further information.

div1.head: Letter from Thomas J. Michie to Philip Showalter Hench, March 4, 1942

opener.dateline:
THOMAS J. MICHIE
KOPPERS BUILDING
PITTSBURGH, PA.
March 4, 1942. Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota

div1.p:
Thank you very much indeed for your interesting letter
of February 27th in response to my recent inquiry.

From what you say of the subsequent career of the Major
Michie in question, he must have been Robert E. Lee Michie, who was
born in Albemarle County, a contemporary and distant cousin (about
fourth) of my father. He is the only Michie that I know of who ever
rose to the rank of a General in the Army. I thought of him when I
first received Atch's letter, but thought it likely that the person
in question was someone else as I did not think that Lee Michie had
risen to the rank of Major at a date as early as that in question.
He was only a Colonel when the First World War broke out in 1917,
though he became a General soon after.

I used to know General Michie myself, as well as his
daughter Margaret, and I have been in recent correspondence with her.
She has written me that she has a number of newspaper clippings
which might interest me in connection with my family researches and
I have intended to call on her some time when I am in New York and
still intend to do so. Doubtless she will have some information on
her father's slight connection with the yellow fever matter. Therefore,
I hardly think it worth while to ask General Kean to go to any trouble
in connection with the matter or to write to the War Department for
General Michie's record.

I am, however, sending a copy of this letter to
General Kean and if by any chance the Major Michie in question should
be someone other than Robert E. Lee Michie, I would appreciate very
much having that information and any further lead that would help me
to trace his connection in the family.

Thanking you for your prompt reply to my inquiry and
with kindest personal regards, I am
